awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Training the next generation of Navajo language scientists
awd_abstract_narration:
The Native American Languages Act, passed by the U.S. Congress in 1990, enacted into policy the recognition of the unique status and importance of Native American languages.  The Navajo language (also called Diné) has more speakers than any other language indigenous to the United States. This is the language of the Code Talkers, United States Marines who developed and employed a code in World War II that was never broken. Despite strong traditions, very few Navajo children are now learning to speak the language which means that it is at great risk of vanishing within a few generations. The complexity of the grammar, which contributed to the code?s security, makes the language difficult to learn in schools.   This project will train the next generation of Navajo Nation language scientists from in language documentation and linguistic analysis, broadening participation by Native Americans in the social sciences. Broader impacts also include working with language teachers on applying the analysis of Navajo grammar to language teaching, which will benefit students in K-12 Navajo classrooms.  The project will also enhance the capacity of the two participating organizations, Navajo Technical University (NTU), a tribal college that offers a variety of educational degrees up to a master's degree in Diné Culture, Language and Leadership and the Navajo Language Academy (NLA), a non-profit educational organization dedicated to the scientific study of Navajo.  


Summer workshops, ongoing since 1997, will focus on applying principles of scientific research to the Navajo language and discovering the rules and principles that underlie its grammar.  Co-directed by linguist Dr. Theodore Fernald from the NLA and cultural anthropologist Dr. Wesley Thomas from NTU, the project will train tribal college students, linguistics students, and Navajo Nation teachers in language documentation and analysis annually.  Learning the necessary linguistics, transcription and annotation skills will enable participating students and language teachers to create materials for a bilingual Navajo digital text corpus with analyzed examples.  Participants and other researchers will use the corpus to develop hypotheses about language data and to test those hypotheses against the corpus using the scientific methods employed by linguists.  The corpus and its recordings will be accessible on-line to provide resources for researchers, teachers, and language learners. NTU students will engage in analysis and work with the corpus throughout the year.  A unique advantage of this planned research is that it is possible because of the two generations of Navajo speakers who were trained in linguistics graduate programs on how to engage in the scientific study of their language, earning doctorates in linguistics and related fields, the type of scenario that linguists argue enables deeper and richer investigations of a language's structure. These summer workshops offer a unique venue for research and teaching Navajo and Dene (Athabaskan) linguistics.  A professional evaluator will develop and implement an assessment plan to gauge the success of NLA and NTU programs.   The NSF Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP)is providing support for tribal college participation in this project.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

There is a strong tradition of Navajo linguistics that stretches back over a hundred years and includes Navajo and non-Navajo linguists. Navajo linguistics is unique in indigenous American linguistics in that several Navajo people have earned PhDs in linguistics. These scholars include Paul Platero, Ellavina Perkins, Alyse Neundorf, MaryAnn Willie, Evangeline Parsons Yazzie, Michele Arviso, and Melvatha Chee. This project aims to contribute to efforts to continue this tradition.

The Navajo Language Academy/Diné Bizaad Naalkaah (NLA) is a non-profit organization of linguists and language teachers from within and outside the Navajo Nation. It is dedicated to supporting research on the grammar and use of the language and supporting language teachers.

Navajo Technical University (NTU) is one of two academic institutions of higher learning in the Navajo Nation. NTU offers Bachelor of Arts and Master of Arts degrees in Dine Culture, Language & Leadership. 

Intellectual Merit

The broad goals for this NSF project were to enhance the capacity of the Navajo Language Academy and Navajo Technical University to work together to support Navajo linguistics and to contribute to the development of a new generation of Navajo linguists. The specific objectives were:

  • To train Navajo language teachers and linguists in documentary, descriptive, and theoretical linguistics, particularly in verb morphology and the use of the Young & Morgan dictionary. 
  • To enhance collaboration between NLA members and NTU faculty and students in order to increase the capacity of both programs.
  • To engage students and Navajo scholars in building digital tools for language analysis and language learning.

These goals and objectives were approached in several ways. The grant supported three NLA Linguistics Institutes, two at NTU and one at Diné College, Tsaile. These programs offered linguistics courses that supplemented NTU?s normal offerings and provided language teachers from across the Navajo Nation with a deeper understanding of the grammar of Navajo and related languages. The grant allowed students to be trained in documentary linguistics at the Institute on Collaborative Language Research (CoLang) in 2016 and 2018, training participants in language documentation and annotation, and in archiving recordings made in the past. The grant supported the Navajo Linguistics Field School /Diné Bizaad Research Experiences (REX) for three years, a program modeled on Research Experiences for Undergraduates (RUE), but allowing graduate students to participate and other scholars to participate. 

The REX program was a project-oriented collaboration of NLA and NTU faculty and students that developed four online language tools, designed to support language teaching, learning and analysis. The first two of these tools are glorified glossaries of postpositions (the Navajo counterpart of English prepositions) and of adverbs. These lexicons include audio recordings of sentences that illustrate the grammatical functions of the postpositions and adverbs, and each sentence appears with a gloss of each significant word part as well as a free translation in English. These two lexicons are available here: 

Navajo Postposition Lexicon

Navajo Adverb Lexicon

The third REX project began development of an online tool designed to explain how to form questions in Navajo. This is more than a lexicon in that it includes a grammatical description of three kinds of Navajo questions (content questions, yes/no questions, and alternatives questions). This website is still under development, but it is already a useful tool:

Navajo Questions: Grammar and examples

The final REX project began development of verb modes. Verb structure is generally considered to be the aspect of Navajo grammar that is the most difficult for non-native speakers to learn. The verb modes include timing information that is similar to tense and aspect in English. The modes are indicated in the verb in the final syllable, usually along with a particular prefix. The current version of this language tool is available here:

Navajo Verb Mode: Grammar and Examples

Due to the covid pandemic, the third and fourth REX projects were conducted remotely through Zoom meetings. 

In all four projects, the participants found or created sentences to illustrate particular grammatical principles, analyzed them, glossed them, and recorded them with their own voices. 

Broader impacts 

An important feature of this project was the training and participation of native speaker students in language documentation, linguistic analysis and development of materials. There is an interest among native speakers and their children to re-learn the language, thus working towards its revitalization. The websites that were developed create the possibility of incorporating many more projects related to other endangered languages in the United States of America, thus disseminating the wealth of information that remains in different collections and research publications. In this way, the project contributes to raising the awareness of the Navajo people about the richness of their linguistic and cultural diversity, and to preserve important documentation about this endangered language for future researchers.
